misconceptions.name: Implemented an entirely different problem (average acceleration) instead of summing even integers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of a program that reads 5 integers and sums only the even numbers. This indicates a misunderstanding or misreading of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles and computes the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process those 5 inputs, check each number with a condition like n % 2 == 0 to determine if it is even, accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers.
Program reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers.
No loop is used to process 5 separate inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0).
No accumulator for summing even numbers; instead, computes (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem statement, possibly confusing it with a different exercise about computing average acceleration.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Identify the required inputs (5 integers), the processing steps (looping through each number, checking if it is even), and the required output (sum of even numbers) before you start writing code.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is tailored to an unrelated physics problem (average acceleration) and does not include any elements required by the given specification (5 integers, even check, sum). This consistently indicates misinterpreting the assignment.

evidence.note: This code clearly solves an average acceleration problem instead of reading 5 integers, checking for even numbers, and summing them.

misconceptions.name: Submitted Code for Incorrect Assignment
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program that calculates the average acceleration (a = (v1 - v0) / t) instead of implementing the solution for 'Sum of Even Numbers'. This submission completely fails to meet any requirements of the assigned question, including input quantity, data filtering logic, looping structure, and calculation goal.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes this code solves the assigned problem, or accidentally submitted code for a different coursework question involving kinematics/acceleration calculations.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading 5 integers, using a loop structure, applying an if-condition to check for evenness (using the modulo operator), and maintaining an accumulator for the sum. The submitted code addresses none of these requirements.
symptoms: Program prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Program calculates 'acceleration' instead of 'sum of even numbers'.
A loop structure is missing.
Conditional logic (if statement) is missing.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpreting or confusing the required assignment. The provided solution is for an unrelated problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the assignment prompt for 'Sum of Even Numbers' and ensure the logic addresses all steps: reading 5 numbers, iterating, checking for evenness, and summing the results.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code solves a well-known physics problem and uses completely different variable names and output than required, indicating definitive submission of the wrong program.

evidence.note: Class name immediately suggests the wrong problem.
The entire core logic is dedicated to calculating average acceleration (kinematics) using 3 double inputs, rather than summing 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student has solved a completely different problem. The assignment asks to read 5 integers and sum the even numbers, but the student's code reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) and calculates acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t. This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should write a program to calculate average acceleration from velocity and time values.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking each one to see if it is even (divisible by 2), and summing only the even numbers, then printing the result.
symptoms: Program reads 3 floating-point numbers instead of 5 integers
Program performs acceleration calculation instead of even number filtering
Output shows 'The average acceleration is...' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: ...'
No loop structure to process 5 inputs
No conditional logic to check if numbers are even
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either read the wrong problem statement, misread the assignment, or copied code from an unrelated problem about kinematics/physics.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to: (1) read 5 integers, (2) loop through them, (3) check if each is even using n % 2 == 0, (4) accumulate the sum of even numbers only, (5) print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence because the submitted code solves an entirely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) with no overlap to the assignment requirements (sum of even numbers). The class name 'AccelerationCalculator', variable names (v0, v1, t), formula, and output message all clearly indicate a different problem domain.

evidence.note: Reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) for acceleration calculation, not 5 integers for even number filtering
Calculates acceleration using physics formula, completely unrelated to the even number sum task
Outputs acceleration result instead of 'Sum of even numbers' as required by the assignment

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and printing the sum of the even numbers. The entire program logic, inputs, and outputs do not address the stated task.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and prints the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even using a condition like n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'
Only three values are read instead of five
No loop is used to process multiple integers
No conditional check for even numbers
Output describes 'average acceleration' instead of 'sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or confused this question with a different assignment (average acceleration) and did not align the program design with the current problem specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and list the exact steps required: (1) read 5 integers, (2) loop over these inputs, (3) for each number, check if it is even using n % 2 == 0, (4) if even, add it to a running total, and (5) after the loop, print the sum of the even numbers with the required message.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to program design
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code fully implements an unrelated acceleration calculation problem and omits every required element of summing even numbers from 5 integers, showing a clear mismatch with the prompt.

evidence.note: The code reads three doubles for v0, v1, and t, computes average acceleration, and prints it, instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misinterpretation of Problem Statement
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating acceleration given initial velocity, final velocity, and time) instead of solving the assigned problem (calculating the sum of five even integers). This demonstrates a failure to understand or follow the core assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were assigned a problem requiring the calculation of uniform acceleration, or they submitted code from a previous assignment without adapting it.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement was to read five integers and sum only the even ones among them.
symptoms: Code attempts to solve a physics problem (acceleration calculation)
Reads only three double values instead of five integers
Uses variables like 'v0', 'v1', and 't'
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the prompt, submitting the wrong file, or failing to adapt existing code to new requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully read all instructions before starting to code. Ensure the final submission addresses the required task: reading 5 integers and calculating the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire code snippet is dedicated to solving an acceleration problem, which is unrelated to the required task of summing even numbers.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates acceleration, which is not the required task (Sum of Even Numbers).

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Number of Inputs and Data Type
misconceptions.description: The requirement was to read 5 integers, but the student's code reads only 3 double values (v0, v1, t). This shows a misunderstanding of how many inputs were required and what data type (integer) they should be.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes 3 inputs of type 'double' are required for the task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Five inputs of type 'int' are required for the calculation.
symptoms: Uses input.nextDouble() three times
Total count of inputs is 3, not 5
misconceptions.root_cause: The code is written for the wrong problem, which dictated the number and type of inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a loop or five separate input calls to read exactly five integers using `input.nextInt()`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Code explicitly uses nextDouble() three times.

misconceptions.name: Missing Iterative Structure
misconceptions.description: Processing five items most efficiently requires a loop (e.g., a for loop). The student's code lacks any looping structure, handling inputs discretely (or for the wrong problem).
misconceptions.student_belief: Inputs can be handled individually without iteration, even if the count is moderately large (5).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: A `for` loop (or `while` loop) is the standard and efficient way to read and process a fixed number of inputs (N=5).
symptoms: Absence of 'for' or 'while' keywords
Repeated variable declaration pattern (for the wrong variables)
misconceptions.root_cause: Focusing on a non-iterative problem (acceleration) or lack of knowledge regarding iteration for input processing.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a `for` loop that iterates 5 times (i=0 to 4) inside which you read and process each integer.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code contains no looping structure whatsoever.

evidence.note: The input reading and calculation logic is entirely sequential and non-iterative, failing the requirement for processing multiple inputs efficiently.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misunderstanding - Wrong Assignment Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student has misinterpreted the problem requirements and submitted code that solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculator) instead of the assigned sum of even numbers problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is to calculate acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t given three inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, identifying which ones are even (n % 2 == 0), and printing their sum.
symptoms: Code prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'
Uses 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs
Calculates and prints acceleration instead of sum
No loop, no conditional check for even numbers, no accumulator
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misunderstanding or misreading of problem requirements; appears to have copied/pasted code from a different assignment
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement. You need to: (1) Read 5 integers in a loop, (2) Check if each is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) Accumulate the sum of even numbers, (4) Print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the submitted code solves a completely different problem from the assignment specification. There is no overlap between the acceleration calculator and the sum of even numbers problem.

evidence.note: Student reads 3 doubles for acceleration calculation instead of 5 integers for sum of even numbers.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Code implements physics formula for acceleration rather than logic to sum even numbers.
Class name indicates this is an acceleration calculator, not a sum of even numbers program.
